message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The combination of recurrent respiratory infections, nasal polyps, and bulky, foul-smelling stools are suggestive of cystic fibrosis (CF). CF is known to cause male infertility due to the absence of the vas deferens. Option A is related to celiac disease, which is not supportive of the patient’s symptoms. Option C is used to diagnose asthma, which is not the most likely diagnosis in this case. Option D is one of the immunoglobulin deficiencies that can increase the risk of recurrent infections, but it is not specifically associated with CF.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including recurrent respiratory infections, nasal polyps, and difficulty flushing stools, are suggestive of cystic fibrosis. The absence of the vas deferens is a characteristic finding in males with cystic fibrosis. Antibodies to endomysium are seen in celiac disease. Positive methacholine challenge test suggests asthma. Deficiency of immunoglobulin A is seen in individuals with selective IgA deficiency.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest cystic fibrosis, which is characterized by recurrent respiratory infections, bulky foul-smelling stools, and poor growth. Nasal polyps and wheezing are common with cystic fibrosis. Absence of the vas deferens is a common finding in male patients with cystic fibrosis. Antibodies to endomysium are associated with celiac disease, and deficiency of immunoglobulin A is associated with selective immunoglobulin A deficiency. Positive methacholine challenge test is associated with asthma, which may be a comorbidity in patients with cystic fibrosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest cystic fibrosis, which is associated with absence of the vas deferens. Antibodies to endomysium are associated with celiac disease, a condition not related to the patient’s symptoms. A positive methacholine challenge test indicates asthma, which may be present, but it is not the primary concern based on the patient’s symptoms. Deficiency of immunoglobulin A is not typically associated with the symptoms described.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The boy's symptoms suggest cystic fibrosis, which is associated with the absence of the vas deferens. Antibodies to endomysium are associated with celiac disease, positive methacholine challenge test is associated with asthma, and deficiency of immunoglobulin A is associated with a variety of immune disorders, but these conditions are not consistent with the patient's symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of persistent respiratory infections and bulky, foul-smelling stools with nasal polyps suggest cystic fibrosis. Absence of the vas deferens is a common finding in male patients with cystic fibrosis. Antibodies to endomysium are specific to celiac disease. Positive methacholine challenge test is diagnostic for asthma. Deficiency of immunoglobulin A is a congenital immunodeficiency disorder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including recurrent respiratory infections, nasal polyps, and bulky, foul-smelling stools suggest cystic fibrosis. Cystic fibrosis is also associated with male infertility due to the absence of the vas deferens. The other answer options are unrelated to cystic fibrosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation suggests cystic fibrosis, which is an autosomal recessive disease that affects the respiratory, digestive, and reproductive systems. The absence of the vas deferens is a diagnostic criterion for males with cystic fibrosis. Antibodies to endomysium are seen in celiac disease, not cystic fibrosis. A positive methacholine challenge test suggests asthma, which is not typically associated with bulky, foul-smelling stools. Deficiency of immunoglobulin A is a primary immunodeficiency disorder, and while it can present with recurrent respiratory infections, it is not typically associated with digestive symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described suggest the patient has cystic fibrosis, which is most commonly associated with an absence of the vas deferens. Antibodies to endomysium would suggest celiac disease, which is not associated with the symptoms described. A positive methacholine challenge test would suggest asthma, which may be present but is not the primary concern based on the symptoms described. Deficiency of immunoglobulin A would suggest some sort of immunodeficiency, but it is not specifically associated with the symptoms described.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including respiratory infections, nasal polyps, and difficulty flushing stools, suggest cystic fibrosis. The absence of the vas deferens is a common finding in males with cystic fibrosis. Antibodies to endomysium are seen in celiac disease, which does not match the symptoms presented. A positive methacholine challenge test indicates asthma, which is not the primary diagnosis here. Deficiency of immunoglobulin A is associated with increased susceptibility to infections, but it is not the most likely diagnosis in this case.
